The first time was when Yahoo rejected a campaign ad featuring Lamon saying “Let’s Go Brandon.”
“It’s incredibly disappointing that Facebook has decided to pull the Super Bowl ad but we shouldn’t be surprised given that one of our opponents is embedded in big tech.”
Facebook’s policies on “weapons, ammunition, or explosives” state that “ads must not promote the sale or use of weapons, ammunition, or explosives,” which includes “ads for weapon modification accessories.”
Lamon’s ad, however, does not directly promote the sale of any weapons.

https://twitter.com/bennyjohnson/status/1493024438182424580?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1493024438182424580%7Ctwgr%5E%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.infowars.com%2Fposts%2Fwatch-the-lets-go-brandon-commercial-that-aired-during-the-super-bowl%2F

Furthermore, after a review of Facebook’s Ad Library by the DCNF, it was found that the platform previously allowed other politicians to run ads featuring firearms such as Las Vegas City Councilwoman Michele Fiore, a Nevada gubernatorial candidate who ran an ad for a week in which she brandished a shotgun.

Facebook decided to pull the campaign’s ads after they have been running for several days claiming they were in violation of their policies regarding “weapons, ammunition, or explosives,” according to an affiliate of the Lamon campaign.

What’s more is that Lamon’s primary opponent, Republican Blake Masters, criticized the ad calling it “absurd and desperate.” Masters is backed by conservative billionaire Peter Thiel who just so happens to be a Facebook board member.
